title: What is leukemia? - Danilo Allegra and Dania Puggioni

multiple-choice.question: What is leukemia, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of cancer that affects the brain and heart.

options.label: B
options.text: A cancer that begins in stem cells found in the bone marrow.

options.label: C
options.text: A disease that affects the liver and skin.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of cancer that affects the lungs and muscles.

multiple-choice.question: Why is leukemia the most common childhood cancer, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is caused by many DNA modifications.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is caused by just one or two DNA modifications.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is caused by a virus.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is caused by a bacterial infection.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main problem with chemotherapy for treating leukemia, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It is too expensive.

options.label: B
options.text: It is too time-consuming.

options.label: C
options.text: It kills healthy cells, such as those found in hair follicles or intestines.

options.label: D
options.text: It does not work for all types of leukemia.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of bone marrow transplants in treating leukemia, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To remove the damaged cells from the body.

options.label: B
options.text: To replace the damaged cells with healthy cells from a donor.

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the dosage of chemotherapy required.

options.label: D
options.text: To improve the patient's immune system.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to find a compatible bone marrow donor, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Because there are too few potential donors.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the search process is too complicated.

options.label: C
options.text: Because there are thousands of HLA types, and even siblings and close relatives may not have compatible bone marrow.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the patient's own bone marrow is not compatible with the donor's.

title: Why neutrinos matter - Sílvia Bravo Gallart

multiple-choice.question: What are neutrinos, and what is unique about them?

options.label: A
options.text: Neutrinos are a type of gas that can be found in the atmosphere, and they are affected by magnetic fields.

options.label: B
options.text: Neutrinos are elementary particles that can't be subdivided, and they fly easily through matter, unaffected by magnetic fields.

options.label: C
options.text: Neutrinos are a type of radiation that can be produced by nuclear reactions, and they are highly interactive with other matter.

options.label: D
options.text: Neutrinos are a type of particle that can be found in the human body, and they are highly affected by temperature changes.

multiple-choice.question: Where are high-energy neutrinos born, and what might be producing them?

options.label: A
options.text: High-energy neutrinos are born in the Earth's core, and they are produced by the Earth's magnetic field.

options.label: B
options.text: High-energy neutrinos are born far out in space in environments that we know very little about, such as supermassive black holes or cosmic dynamos.

options.label: C
options.text: High-energy neutrinos are born in the atmosphere, and they are produced by the interaction of cosmic rays with the atmosphere.

options.label: D
options.text: High-energy neutrinos are born in nuclear reactors, and they are produced by the radioactive decay of nuclear materials.

multiple-choice.question: How do scientists detect neutrinos, and what is unique about the IceCube neutrino telescope?

options.label: A
options.text: Scientists detect neutrinos by using a large magnet to attract them, and the IceCube neutrino telescope is a small detector located in the Arctic Circle.

options.label: B
options.text: Scientists detect neutrinos by using a large volume of pure transparent material, such as ice, to reveal themselves by colliding with the nucleus of an atom, and the IceCube neutrino telescope is the world's largest neutrino telescope.

options.label: C
options.text: Scientists detect neutrinos by using a large array of detectors to measure the energy of the neutrinos, and the IceCube neutrino telescope is a small detector located in Antarctica.

options.label: D
options.text: Scientists detect neutrinos by using a large nuclear reactor to produce them, and the IceCube neutrino telescope is a small detector located in the United States.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the collisions between neutrinos and matter, and how do scientists detect these collisions?

options.label: A
options.text: The collisions between neutrinos and matter are highly energetic and produce a lot of radiation, and scientists detect these collisions by using a large magnet to attract the radiation.

options.label: B
options.text: The collisions between neutrinos and matter are extremely rare and produce a small amount of radiation, and scientists detect these collisions by using a large volume of pure transparent material to reveal themselves by colliding with the nucleus of an atom.

options.label: C
options.text: The collisions between neutrinos and matter are highly interactive and produce a lot of particles, and scientists detect these collisions by using a large array of detectors to measure the energy of the particles.

options.label: D
options.text: The collisions between neutrinos and matter are highly affected by temperature changes and produce a lot of heat, and scientists detect these collisions by using a large nuclear reactor to produce them.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the IceCube neutrino telescope, and what might it reveal about the universe?

options.label: A
options.text: The IceCube neutrino telescope is a small detector located in Antarctica, and it is used to study the properties of neutrinos.

options.label: B
options.text: The IceCube neutrino telescope is the world's largest neutrino telescope, and it is used to study the highest energy cosmic neutrinos and their origins.

options.label: C
options.text: The IceCube neutrino telescope is a small detector located in the United States, and it is used to study the properties of cosmic rays.

options.label: D
options.text: The IceCube neutrino telescope is a small detector located in the Arctic Circle, and it is used to study the properties of neutrinos in the Earth's core.

title: What's the difference between accuracy and precision? - Matt Anticole

multiple-choice.question: What is the key difference between accuracy and precision?

options.text: Accuracy involves how consistently you can get a result, while precision involves how close you come to the correct result.

title: Stroke of insight - Jill Bolte Taylor

multiple-choice.question: What motivated Dr. Jill Bolte Taylor to dedicate her career to researching severe mental illnesses?

options.label: A

options.text: She suffered from a traumatic brain injury.

options.label: A

options.label: B

title: How we think complex cells evolved - Adam Jacobson

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called when one organism absorbs another organism and they unite to become a new organism with the combined abilities of both?

options.label: A
options.text: Endosymbiosis

options.label: B
options.text: Photosynthesis

options.label: C
options.text: Mitosis

options.label: D
options.text: Meiosis

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the theory that explains the origin of the vast variety of eukaryotic organisms?

options.label: A
options.text: The Endosymbiotic Theory

options.label: B
options.text: The Cellular Theory

options.label: C
options.text: The Genetic Theory

options.label: D
options.text: The Evolutionary Theory

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the main pieces of evidence that supports the endosymbiotic theory?

options.label: A
options.text: The chloroplasts and mitochondria in our cells multiply the same way as those ancient bacteria.

options.label: B
options.text: The chloroplasts and mitochondria both contain their own DNA and ribosomes.

options.label: C
options.text: The membranes involved in the engulfing process have two membranes surrounding them.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the structures that work together to harness sunlight, make sugar, and break down that sugar using the oxygen that appeared in the Earth's atmosphere?

options.label: A
options.text: Chloroplasts and mitochondria

options.label: B
options.text: Nucleus and ribosomes

options.label: C
options.text: Cell membrane and cytoplasm

options.label: D
options.text: Flagella and cilia

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the absorbing process of endosymbiotic theory?

options.label: A
options.text: Species that are less adapted to life on Earth.

options.label: B
options.text: Species that are more adapted to life on Earth.

options.label: C
options.text: Species that are the same as when they were separate organisms.

options.label: D
options.text: Species that are extinct.

title: History vs. Richard Nixon - Alex Gendler

options.text: He was tired of being in office.

options.label: C
options.text: He wanted to focus on his personal life.

options.text: He was offered a better job opportunity.

multiple-choice.question: What was the Watergate scandal, and what was President Nixon's role in it?

options.label: A
options.text: The Watergate scandal was a burglary that President Nixon ordered, and he was directly involved in covering it up.

options.label: B
options.text: The Watergate scandal was a burglary that President Nixon's men broke into the Democratic National Committee headquarters, and he did everything to cover it up.

options.label: C
options.text: The Watergate scandal was a burglary that President Nixon's men broke into the Democratic National Committee headquarters, and he had no knowledge of it.

options.label: D
options.text: The Watergate scandal was a scandal that President Nixon was falsely accused of being involved in.

multiple-choice.question: What were some of President Nixon's accomplishments during his time in office?

options.label: A
options.text: He ended the Vietnam War, created the Environmental Protection Agency, and lowered the voting age to 18.

options.label: B
options.text: He proposed the creation of the Environmental Protection Agency, signed the National Environmental Policy Act into law, and expanded the Clean Air Act.

options.label: C
options.text: He signed the Title IX amendment, banned gender-based discrimination in education, and ensured that desegregation of schools occurred peacefully.

options.label: D
options.text: He ended the Vietnam War, created the Environmental Protection Agency, and lowered the voting age to 18, but also had some negative policies.

multiple-choice.question: What was President Nixon's stance on the civil rights movement?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a strong supporter of the civil rights movement and advocated for the rights of African Americans.

options.label: B
options.text: He courted Southern voters through fear and resentment of the civil rights movement.

options.label: C
options.text: He had mixed views on the civil rights movement and sometimes supported it, but also sometimes opposed it.

options.label: D
options.text: He was not involved in the civil rights movement.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of President Nixon's resignation, and how did it impact his legacy?

options.label: A
options.text: His resignation was a major achievement for democracy, and it showed that leaders are accountable to the people.

options.label: B
options.text: His resignation was a minor event that had no impact on his legacy.

options.label: C
options.text: His resignation was a necessary step to end the Vietnam War.

options.label: D
options.text: His resignation was a result of his many accomplishments in office.
